More preaching to the choir. Come November 2020, I will vote in my overwhelmingly blue state for the Democratic candidate and then watch as a few swing states decide who will be president. What else can I do? If Trump is to be stopped before then it will take those now in power to do it.

While I share Mr. Egan's  opinion  , I am certain of another thing. Trump supporters are no longer the run of the mill  republicans of yore. They have latched onto a cult of  crudity unmatched in American politics. They enshrine Trump, they congratulate his low brow approach to politics and they readily despise fellow citizens for not thinking as they do.  My hope is that in November, a sizeable enough number of voters will wash this septic  administration  away.

How long can a "good person" do nothing and still be considered good? 
Among my concerns about Biden, his repeated insistence that there are many good decent GOP politicians just waiting with baited breath to start acting honorably and bargaining in good faith simply beggars belief. 
The politicians who populate the modern GOP are ringwraiths, perfectly willing to follow Trump wherever he takes them if they think the path leads to reelection. GOP pols, at least on the national stage, have shown all of us who they are. We need to believe them.

But fight how? Fine. Voting. But how else? I think what has to happen is jobs and people moving to red states. All big tech companies who are looking to open H2s should move - jobs and people - to the reddest states. This is the only way.

I feel Mr. Egan’s pain. But has America ever been ‘great’? Mr. Trump is but the worst example of what a significant part of our country has always been - resistant to change, rooted in a familiar past long gone, wedded to simplistic answers, and uninterested in the laws that form the framework of a democratic government. Go back in time to every decade in our past and there will be the forces of the reactionary right, feeding off the fears and narrowness of an uneducated and manipulated populace. What perhaps has changed is that a bottom feeder such as Trump has been allowed to scramble to the top of the podium. In previous years he would have been vetted out. But make no mistake, we have been here before. Pay Buchanan, Joe McCarthy, George Wallace, Huey Long - the list goes on and on. They may be gone, but the millions who followed them? They’re still around.

Trump's lifelong record as a person and businessman should have eliminated him as a candidate -- for anything.  Instead, some voters eager for change decided to elect someone who looks good on TV, and is slick with insults, and hollow promises.  I hope that three years of this shameful administration has taught us a lesson. We now know that news bulletins, polls  and social media are flawed methods to judge a leader.  We need leaders with good character and values-the  same virtues that created our nation. We should expect the same from our elected officials.  Mr. Trump has never met those standards-- and never will.  It's time  to end this embarrassing moment in our country's history. As for Trump and his political cronies, they will have a place in history --as  our nation's worst example of leadership.   Let's not elect any more contenders for that distinction.

Thanks, Mr Egan for the reminder that evil flourishes when good people do nothing. I have a history of speaking up for the greater good but your article made me aware how increasingly I’m an ostrich with her head in the sand, so sickened am I by the ugliness in the White House and the do-nothing Republican senators, who seem to revel in bullying and free passes to criminal behavior. At times, it feels like a giant wave of ugly has washed away all good in America. I must fight back, stand up, speak up, particularly now. For the greater good. For my candidate of choice: Elizabeth Warren.

On the morning of November 9, 2016, I woke up thinking "Evil has won." Leading up to the election, I had a manichean sense that we were witnessing an epic battle between good and big bad. The other candidate wasn't perfect, but she and her party represented the effort to make America, and the world, a better place for more people. As Mr. Egan points out, it was clear from the start that Mr. Trump, and his enablers, had no heart, no humility, and cared not a fig for the common person. Add the silt layers of mendacity, depravity, and utter contempt for the Constitution and for truth, and you have Mr. Trump and the GOP in a rancid nutshell.

Is the author saying that those of us who already think Trump is evil are doing nothing?  Because I disagree.  We're trying to elect people who will oppose him and a person who will replace him in 2020.  We did elect people who impeached him.  These are the best things we can do in our system.

If the author is talking about the Trump believers, then yes, they've sold their souls.  But lumping in the people who oppose him is not fair.  Doing the things I state above are effective.  Screaming and raging about it just makes living through this horrible time that much more stressful, and we're all at our limit on stress.

He has been aided and abetted by an echo chamber of toxic media and by enough self-interested or single-issue religious leaders willing to betray their faiths.   

The key issue is how can we restore the values of the country after this concerted effort to destroy them?   Has Trump irrevocably conveyed the message that being "good" just for suckers now?  How impeachment is handled may well signal our commitment to values post-Trump.

The charges against Trump, just short of treason, should make duped senators think twice. 

What cannot be brought as evidence in the trial are the evil things Mr. Egan describes.  But the republican acquiescence and destruction of our decency and compassion  should be as wall paper; seen but not heard. There, always, a reminder of how disastrous Trump et al are.

When I hear the talking heads on television say that history will not be kind to these complicit Republicans, I wonder what are they talking about.

These people don’t care about history.  They don’t care about the future as the continent of Australia is on fire and they are looking for new ways to drill baby drill and further pollute our fragile planet for profit.  They don’t care about the past reputation of this once respected country as Trump abandons our allies and aligns himself to dictators.

They don’t care about anything but the here and now, retaining their power and not alienating Trump’s cult.  Nothing else matters to them.

It’s up to us to mobilize and vote these people out as long as we still have that power.

It is clear as day what is happening in plain sight, what has hit this nation, what contributed to this failure, what the global ripple effects may be. This is an historic time. Never, not even in WW2, has democracy in the world faced a challenge like this from within. The top is blowing off the big tent and the next few years will reveal how deep the decay has penetrated. People are right to be deeply troubled and disturbed by all of this. It is just that bad.

There is an ugly side to human nature that is in all of us.  Primitive emotions; hatred, anger, cruelty, are powerful human emotions; contagious is the right word for it.  Trump instinctively knows how to tap into those emotions.

That's what the Trump movement is: a hate movement; a societal immaturity.  This also explains whey it's so heavily male.  We all have to resist the instinct and look to the better angels of our nature.

Hey, many of us do fight, and resist, all the time.   We donate, we volunteer, we phone tree and text chain and will carpool voters and make sure those lawyers are out there to fight voter suppression, even though it's exhausting.

The problem, though, is that the other side, while not the majority, is a very substantial minority, big enough in our distorted system of money=speech=power to have outsized influence, and just as fanatically, zealously dedicated to their Puritan/Calvinist/Prosperity Gospel view of the need for a white male dominated world as we may be to a more diverse and egalitarian one. 

There are, of course, a lot of people in the apathetic pocket who might be persuaded to add their voices and efforts--but because they're apathetic, and low information, they are as susceptible to the racist, xenophobic, sexist arguments as they might be to more egalitarian ones.

I fear that there may not be a movement towards concerted action by an overwhelming majority until there's some major terrorist or climate disaster--and even then that action has no guarantee of being salutary.  Our reaction to 9/11 squandered the sympathy of the world and did not help our situation.

It may be that our national character is just too greedy and exclusive to evolve towards something like a Northern European system--and we may wind up very much like nationalist, xenophobic Russia or China.

The problem is this 'evil' is supported by money, money, money.
It flourishes because the good people do nothing because they have money and more money and anticipate even more money.
Outrage over the killing of an Iranian General lasts 24 hours while the "market" worries about oil prices. In the next 24 hours, oil prices stabilize and the worries about the killing begin to fade - quickly. Why worry when your money is safe again.
The greed of the Trumpian Wall Street is justification enough for allowing Trump to continue his evil acts. And this twisted 'logic' follows through to the average American voter. The phrase "it's the economy stupid" has never been more true than under Trump's rule.

I disagree with one point in Mr. Egan’s column. The greater (not smaller) evils are the Republican senators who know the president violated his oath and deserves to be impeached, but don’t have the guts to say so.

The Republican Party was corrupt, cruel, and deprived long before Donald Trump. He won for a reason and they support him in mass for a reason. There in lies the much bigger problem, for even if trump is removed, we still have Trump in ever last House and Senate Republican and in all the federal and Supreme Court Justices and in the leadership at Fox News. You ain’t seen nothing yet. This ain’t going away when Trump goes.

Trump does not deserve so much credit.  Without the diehard support of the Republican Senate, Trump would have been marginalized long ago.  

Decent people wonder why the Republicans have sunk so low.  

The answer is that they have not sunk lower.  Trump is the poster child who most clearly and consistently expresses Republican mores and values.

Give credit where credit is due.  Under the Republican Party, "the United States is a confederacy of corruption, driven by a thousand points of evil. And that evil is contagious."

I am not "desensitized" to Trump's evil. Nor will I ever forgive the people who voted for him and still support him. 

But what can I do? I attend Indivisible meetings. I write and call my elected officials. I give what money I can to causes that help the environment, fight current atrocities (children in cages) and the people running against Mitch McConnell, Susan Collins, etc. And, most importantly, I vote in EVERY election. 

But I'm not a billionaire able to buy myself my own politician and I'm frankly tired of articles that blame the majority for being "desensitized" to the evil of current Republicans and the destruction of our country. The people I know are in despair one minute and fighting mad the next but we're just ordinary folks who don't matter to anyone in power.

The warning is being rewritten: the only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good to do something — and find that it means nothing.

It has become quite clear that as long as Republicans hold on to their sliver-thin majority in the Senate, "doing something" does nothing.

There are lots of good people 'doing something,' and taking risks. That is being successfully stonewalled.

The only opportunity to 'do something' left is the election — in particular, not just replacing trump, but the majority leadership of the Senate.

And everything is being done on the part of trump, McConnell and Barr to corrupt that process.

Trump defends his every illegal act by citing our ever rising stock market and supposedly booming economy.  It is as if he thinks that any act is justified as long as money is being made.  Perhaps he is right.  Maybe money is the only measure of the value of the United States of America.  I was always taught that we stood for more than simple greed.  Silly me.

Nice column but I would add this - Trump hasn't created any of this he simply leveraged it. We are all in our bubbles and for those of us who occasionally tune into "hate" radio or Faux News it is impossible to not notice that Trump is beloved because he hates all the right people. We are in a culture war.

The shame of it all is that Trump is the face of America, and more shameful is the fact that people in my country believe that our good fortune via our Share Market is because of Trump, and they are quite chuffed with him. Soon the bubble will burst as they always do, but the depths his devotees allow him to sink speaks volumes in regards to their complete and utter absence of decency

Rage against the other is simply the divisive nature we have all promoted.  If this democracy is to survive, we must find ways to accept and appreciate a spectrum of ideas, to compromise and collaborate, to search for love, respect and hope across the diversity we represent, not this constant will to establish warring sides for constant battle with the intense ability to hate and fear one another.

The Times and other mainstream media gives us page upon page, hour upon hour, non stop covering, quoting, analyzing Trump, amplifying his message, and occasionally critiquing his spineless GOP enablers. But comparably little attention is given to the millions of people mobilized in various organizations and activities across this country resisting Trumps policies, divisiveness, ugliness and insults!  The national mood thus appears dour, we worry that Trump will win again. Please cover the resistance more!  Trump does not define America. The people fighting against him do.  But they seem to have a hard time getting the media’s attention.

The irony of freedom is the necessity of rules.  Without them, freedom degenerates into the will of the powerful.

The surest we to lose our freedom as a country is to give too much of it to the powerful.

The disingenuous argument by Trump supporters has emerged that their hero is being unjustly impeached simply because Democrats "don't like" the president.  This specious line of reasoning appeals to many in its simplicity, but conveniently ignores our leader's uniquely manipulative mobster mentality, which is, and has been, the hallmark of the Trump brand.

That so many Americans seem to have accepted Trump's menu of corruption, sweetened by economic prosperity, suggests that the evil that has taken root in the White House may be more than contagious.  Sadly, it may be endemic.

“There is no bottom. There is no shame. There are no limits.” 

The Americans from all walks of life, who stopped their ears, covered their eyes, lost their voices, or worse, allowed themselves to be mightily entertained by this venomous human being, from the GOP nominating process onward, have all contributed to placing us in the ever accelerating downward spiral on which we now find ourselves. 

Mr. Egan is right about the contagion of evil, and for me, this period of American history under Trump might as well be described as “The Plague Years.”

As Trump has proven, we as a people are petty, bigoted, amoral, and selfish. There always was a very thin veneer of principle covering these faults which has been scraped away by the Trump cultists.
The most disappointing thing for me about the last 4 years is finding out just what kind of people my neighbors and co-workers are.

Thank you. I cringe when I hear a supporter say, “well, the economy is doing all right.” What swing voters MUST realize is that this is not a normal policies-based political struggle. The most left-wing Democrat, or the most conservative Republican, should have your vote over Trump, if you are a thinking, sentient human being who has any understanding of our small-r republican principles. His corruption, ignorance, and lack of Constitutional fiber matter more than any of the traditional differences between the parties.
It is disgusting to think --to realize-- that the day is here when Americans, as visitors to our (former?) ally countries will find ourselves viewed by our old, once-friends as, well, disgusting.

“Do not come to this fight believing that the Trump team views any action, including outright criminality, as off limits,” 

This is the best description of trump and pals I have seen in the last four years. What really distresses me the most about this is how very large the trump team is while I have to wonder what their motive is. From what I can see 99% of the GOP congress will cover up anything trump does while 40% of America will do the same. All this to maybe overturn Roe vs Way, expel brown people from America, make the rich richer and the poor poorer. Its a very sad day here at home.

Mr. Egan should have mentioned the catalyst for Trump's various depraved narratives. For example, where did the Edward Gallagher as hero story begin? It boiled up from far-right websites before going primetime on Fox News. I would argue that evil is allowed to flourish every day and night on a major US network.

"The Trump presidency has shown just how many ostensibly good people will do nothing, and how evil, when given a free rein at the top, trickles down."

It seems to be the only thing that actually trickles down.

I would argue that a significant portion of second world America acts evil.  We need to pull the plug, stop the transfer of wealth, and let them deal with the consequences of their decisions not to adapt to modernity.

The Republican Party has not been mistaken in underestimating Trump's evil, the party has made no  mistake in judgement. What has happened over the past three years is the gradual, partial unveiling of the party's own evil.

But the full frontal reveal of Republican evil is about to start. The Senate impeachment "trial" of Trump is putting Republican immorality and pure partisanship on stage, front and center. Stripped of their bloody shirt of phony patriotism, their threadbare veil of decency, their pretense of honor, we see depraved Republican senators nakedly reveling in and celebrating evil.

Republican Senators are mocking the efforts of Democrats and all Americans, to stand up to evil. Trump and Republicans in Congress dared Democrats to call out his crimes against the Constitution and when they did, Republicans enthusiastically projected his crimes onto Speaker Pelosi and House Democrats, falsely accusing them of abuse of power and trampling the Constitution. Now Senate Republicans are orchestrating a sham trial.

They ludicrously and offensively attack House Democrats and the impeachment proceedings to distract public attention from compelling evidence of Trump's crimes. They are engaged in a cover-up and are contemptuous of any who point it out.

You decry the ostensibly good people who do nothing-that is not the surprise.The shock is that so many ostensibly good people have joined the Trump bandwagon enthusiastically and cheer and shout at his rallies.They don’t ignore his evil-they seem to embrace it.Some of us who have lived a long life have seen this before-during World War Two we heard the chants and salutes.It is chilling to see some of the similarities!

Where are the bumper stickers and public outcries? Is everyone numb? After 9/11 we used to discuss the government atrocities, but now everyone is too scared to “bring it up” in case the person you thought was good turns out to be the opposite.  
We need a leader with a strong and powerful voice who can save this democracy. I thought that person was Elizabeth Warren, but she gets caught up in the silliness, like all of the candidates.

Trump is the Picture of Dorian Grey. Like the portrait that reflected Dorian's soul , Trump reflects a really dark aspect of America and the world.  Across the planet, evil men looking to Trump as example and guide  are rising to power .

"The smaller evils are the Republican senators who know the president violated his oath and deserves to be impeached, but don’t have the guts to say so."

And we are about to witness the most pernicious of evils:  when a large majority of Republican senators, if not all of them, will violate their oath to "do impartial justice according to the Constitution and laws." and acquit Donald Trump of the high crimes and misdemeanors he has so blatantly committed.

It is no longer hyperbole to say that such acquittal, in removing all checks on the conduct of the President of the United States, will be the equivalent of the Reichstag's Enabling Act of 1933.

Then we shall see the full consequences of unleashing this evil upon the world.

The second piece today establishing our situation on the basis of good and evil.  There are others not represented here who do not see themselves as having made a deal with the devil, or at least not more so than those they oppose.
The piece calls to mind those often repeated words, 'God is on our side', much the same now but without invoking the deity.
I don't see Bernie engaging in this sort of thing, beyond pointing out that wealth, in historic terms, seems to have concentrated power enabling desensitized consideration of and policies affecting the non thriving; still, others are human and, within our communities, our brothers and sisters.
A place to start.

On this point, the body on trial now in the impeachment proceedings is the US Senate.  Someone has to be a leader and break this partisan log jam.  To let the President's behavior, clearly illegal, even immoral, and personally motivated, go unchecked is to lower the bar of civility and decorum permanently, and while it may smack of hand wringing to say, democracy itself is at risk.

"A confederacy of corruption, driven by a thousand points of evil" is a perfect summary of the past three years. I disagree though that the depravity exists solely within the administration and its enablers. The depravity extends far beyond this relatively small group to many supporters of the current administration regardless of their individual motivations. 

As a realist, I cannot help but think this depravity will prevail in November. If so, it may signal the beginning of the end of the great American experiment. Empires do not last forever as history teaches us. Perhaps it is time to contemplate what comes next. If such comes to pass, I would hope for a peaceful separation in order that those of us striving to better the planet for its current inhabitants and save it for future generations may get on with tackling the challenges of the 21st century.

"Here’s the two-step that all good people must take now: First, realize the level of depravity that has taken over the White House, and second, fight accordingly."

I am 1000% on board with step 1.  On to step 2.  My challenge is, how do I as Joe Citizen, 'fight accordingly'?  I vote, I've written to my congressional representatives and I've donated money to candidates in races outside my state that I feel are pivotal.  But I feel this is all a drop of water in the ocean when the President, multiple times a day, lies, misuses his power, assassinates the character of good people, and moves us closer and closer to a state of chaos.

As the impeachment trial, I hope that all the senators who have sworn an oath of impartiality are held to that oath.  They are the people who are best in a position to do something, to fully act on Mr Egan's step 2.  If they fail to take this oath seriously, even if sitting by idly while the trial progresses, they should be named and held accountable.

Absolute Power Corrupts Absolutely

Absolute Power always corrupts the person yielding said power --
or Absolute Power always corrupts those within the sphere of such power.

Lord Acton's letter (quote attributed to a letter from Lord Acton in the late 1800s) suggests the former. However, I've heard some scholars interpret it in the latter sense.

And we can see that with our dear leader, Mr Trump

His current cabinet, staff and most Republican members of congress seem to have abandoned their principles to remain within his sphere of power.

Trump's malfeasance seemed almost predictable. That of so many Republican members of congress is far, far more surprising and disheartening.

I hope the woke people commenting here will VOTE BLUE NO MATTER WHO and VOLUNTEER in KEY states with one of the many organizations that are ready to help. Phone banking and handwritten postcards CAN make a difference.

I am beginning to believe that the true root of evil is willful ignorance. Nothing good can from refusing to accept reality.

Fearful people inherently are at high risk for this behavior. Those that test high in levels of authoritarianism are fearful people by nature, and when provoked or encouraged to show their fear, will do so almost always first by refusing to accept that their worldview is flawed. In defense of their worldview, they deny reality to desperately protect sense of self. As this snowballs, this defensive behavior knows no limits. This is the key to why the very religious can and almost always will support an authoritarian leader, such as Trump. Authoritarian followers respond to fear. Evil is an insidious monster that grows gradually, but always starts with refusal to accept our worst fears.

Just to be clear: “the Trump team” is the GOP. And their “ain’t so but so what if it is” defense has worked almost without fail for 20 years. Rick should know. Trump made them realize there are no limits to how far they can take it. We’re about to experience the proof of that in the Senate.

Re “The president has shown us exactly what happens when good people do nothing.”

Across the great arc of human history democracy stands as a novelty. We are more disposed to organize our societies as monarchies or other autocratic systems. 
Depending on good people standing up against the bad asks too much of them. They need a system that protects them. We used to have one of those.

Thank you for this well-written explanation of the damage we have done to ourselves. The idea of American exceptionalism has done nothing but blind us to our own fallibility, faults, and human nature, precisely because we think it can't happen here.  Pride goes before the fall, or so I've heard. I fear it's not going to end well.

The Senators should have been offered to choose between 2 separate oaths: impartial justice or selective impartial justice. That way they would not have to desecrate their oath in front of the Chief Justice.

Perhaps we should stop focusing all our attention for a moment on Trump and start focusing on the question of how the supposedly great democracy system we live under elected such a manifestly unsuitable man to be President and thereby put in serious jeopardy the future of our Republic. 
The whole electoral system is dysfunctional and the so called 'checks and balances' do not either check or balance the outrageous behavior of a man like Trump. 
To be in a position where our very existence as a democracy is threatened is completely unacceptable and we should all be up in arms demanding that the entire government and judicial edifice be reformed so that it can never happen again.

It seems like some sort of mass hysteria has gripped half of the country.

Maybe much of it is ignorance rather than evil but regardless of what it is it's hard to fathom and hopefully enough people will wake up and start to realize the depth of Trump’s evil during the course of the trial and change their minds for November.

It functions through repeated exposures (Tweets and rallies).  The stimuli is felt to be positive, desirable, pleasurable and rewarding to the addicted person (it really isn't).

Yes, yes, a thousand times YES!  Thank you for so eloquently speaking my truth, Tim.  If only everyone recognized the truth of the pure evil of this "man" and his minions. I have always loved politics and I have always believed in staying current with the news of the world, but these past years of evil under T (he shall not be named) has sapped me of strength, hope and joy. In this time of evil, the stock market hits records highs.  People are employed and have money, so all is well.  We see that self-interest and evil are twin sons of a society in deep denial of who we really are.

Just waking up to the danger of what evil is right in front of us?

I live in a state that unwisely enacted term limits for the state legislature. The result was an increase in the influence of lobbyists and an increase in the power of the governor. It has cut off the stream of young legislators who cut their political teeth in the legislature where learned the ropes of government before moving on to run for statewide office. They had a chance to develop some name recognition because of their work. Now our statewide offices go to millionaires whose families can fund their elections and those the lobbying community wants.

I would like to propose term limits for billionaires.  Upon reaching that ridiculous number, higher and higher levels of scrutiny and transparency on all their holdings would obtain.  For example, the ratio between their lowest paid employees and their own pay would have to narrow. Or if we are just discussing investment income, higher tax rates in proportion to assessed total wealth might be involved.  Smarter people than me could figure this out in a way so as once you reach the sky, you are forced to consider what is going on to the earthbound.  Everyone, billionaires included, return to the earth.

The GOP congressman in the district next to mine was part of the '94 class with their Contract with America and the term limits pledge which he swore he would follow. Yeah, right.  He's still there 12 terms later along with the help of a bunch of hardcore gerrymandering to help him lock down the seat. If anyone is honest about reform, there needs to be fair nonpartisan redistricting everywhere, not term limits.

I agree in principle that term limits are not desirable; that the people should choose when an elected official has served enough terms.  However, this assumes free and fair elections; it does not assume a U.S. system where Supreme Court decisions on the Constitution have prohibited Congress from applying real spending limits on elections.  Until we figure out how to change this system, a term limits requirement is the only mechanism available to prevent politicians' original good intentions being co-opted  by well-heeled lobbyists and donors.  

We have had terms limits for the President for decades; I don't hear anyone complaining that this has been a problem.  New York City has had term limits for its offices for some time now, and there is no question that it has produced a better class of local legislators and citywide officials.  Meanwhile, in my experience, third terms and beyond in State and local offices have been abominations--the officials' best people leave after one or two terms; the officials starts to get lazy, entitled or corrupt, with at best no improvements or innovations happening after the first two terms.  

If you wonder why almost all of the leaders of the Senate are old white males from small population states--thereby wielding excessively disproportionate power over the country--you can blame the absence of terms limits.

I think this opinion is more a screed about presidential power and the concern that the imposition of term limits allows the executive branch to wreak havoc on government and therefore the citizenry.
What we have learned during the last three years is that there is a branch of government responsible for making the wheels turn – the bureaucracy that has evolved into a government within the government. Given the devolution of the power of the press, this deeply experienced bureaucracy is the new “Fourth Estate”.
What really needs to happen is to change the terms of how the bureaucracy operates – let us use elections to select and approve both houses of congress, the executive branch AND the judicial branch. 
Change the law so that the members of both houses of Congress, the Presidency and especially the courts are assigned experienced staff – no more political appointments, but experienced, aids who can guide elected officials in their decision making.
The elected office holder will still be the maker of the final decision, but they will do so with the guidance of someone who has already been there and done that. Elected members of the government could make limited staff changes from time-to-time.
A final change would involve the courts, Use elections to limit the appointment of former circuit judges to a maximum of three, use experienced state judges who have no ties to the federal bench and limit the approval of candidates to a bipartisan subset of elected representatives.

Term limits can be designed to allow us both the benefits of experience and some protection against oligarchy:

We need to increase creative discourse, and much of creativity is derived from both inspiration and experience.

So, if we had only "consecutive" term limits--say two terms as senator, four terms as representative--then people with experience and continuing interest would be encouraged to remain in some form of participation, without the potential for entrenchment of power and oligarchic class.

My examples about "how many" consecutive terms would be one of the subjects for this discourse.

I for one am all for term appointments when it comes to Federal Judges. It seems to me that 20 years would be long enough to retain some of the expertise Mr Bouie is worried about. At the same time a term limit would ensure that a regular turnover would help to keep the courts fresh and up to date.

We seem to have a collective fantasy that we can operate this Nation with simple solutions like "term limits" and "smaller government".  We also think we can run this vast enterprise on the cheap, hence "no new taxes".
There are 300 million of us, living on a continent that is bordered by the two great oceans, with multitudes of cultures and habits and people.  This United States of America is a vast complex mechanism that really doesn't allow for these outdated cliches.
The question and discussion that need be addressed is somewhat simple: Are we One Nation, willing to work together, all of US, to make life better for all of US; or are we a collection of tribes and regions and prejudices that does not allow us to govern as one Nation?
Perhaps it is time to break up into regional and city states and just forget about the United States of America.

We already have de facto term limits, in that any House or Senate member comes up for re-election periodically.

Why get rid of someone who is doing a good job? Why keep someone who isn't?

What we need is for voters to use the power they have. Vote in midterm elections. Research the candidates instead of just voting for the candidate you have heard of or the one who has a nice-looking family or the one who has the loudest TV ads.

Thanks for this - I have been aware of the research you cite of the negative impacts of term limits in those states that have enacted them. It frustrates me to no end that so many people think this wrongheaded policy will solve our problems - you show very well that if anything, term limits will make our problems worse. Term limits undermines our democracy rather than strengthens it, exactly the wrong direction we should be going in.

There are some arguments to be made for term limits--after all, we did institute it for the Presidency--and some arguments to make against them.

But a far more important lever to open up the political system, and perhaps get representatives actually representing their constituents and not just the rich oligarchs who fund their campaigns currently, is full public funding of elections, with no organizational contributions (be they from unions, companies, chambers of commerce, churches, or 5-0-whatevers) allowed, and a very low (three-digit) limit on individual contributions per race.

That's enough to satisfy the "free speech" argument--as free speech can only be the right of an individual, not a group entity, and one should not be able to buy 'more free speech".

A well reasoned, concisely documented argument favoring no term limits. Trouble is, congress is too populated with elderly white men, many having been there for decades. Term limits will help foster change. Fresh faces are important. Even if some are elderly male and white. Just so long as they haven't been there, seemingly forever. Gaining a congressional seat should be hugely competitive. Term limits help ensure this.
It might be useful to increase the number of legislators we have.

Missouri is an example of a state with strict term limits and a House and Senate that is totally out of touch with the voters. I have been pointing out that the term limits have indeed made the local politicians less interested in the voters than in where their career will take them after they are forced to leave office. For many it becomes a job as a lobbyist, or with a corporation for whom they have passed key legislation. 
I appreciate this article because this is a tough argument to make with voters who are already frustrated with Congressional deadlock.  We really need some serious research to analyze the effects of term limits.
Counterpoint: Mitch McConnell was first elected in 1984, has been reelected five times, and has done immeasurable damage to American democracy.

Term limits would fix some problems and create new ones, which is typical. What Bouie asserts would be an effect of term limits -- namely, a weak, deferential, and manipulatable legislature -- is the case George Will routinely makes for their implementation, as today's careerists concerned with reelection won't make difficult decisions as long as they can avoid them; when they can, they offload them to courts, bureaucrats, and the executive. Limiting the House to four terms, the Senate to two, would likely have at least as many beneficial as bad effects. https://www.nationalaffairs.com/publications/detail/a-madisonian-reform "With a limited tenure awaiting a new member, and the returns on any given election thus diminishing, why serve unless it is to assert one's authority for purposes that conduce to a view of the public good? ... Term-limited members ... would be less able to monetize relationships of short duration. The knowledge that one cannot be re-elected permanently reduces the urgency of each intervening election, freeing members of Congress to [stop] punting the responsibility to executive agencies or courts." The problems with the national legislature aren't exactly the same as those at the state level. More of Congress's work should be shielded from public view; of that I have no doubt (not that this will ever happen). I'm open to term limits and Seventeenth Amendment repeal, but am less certain of their effects, particularly the former.

I too strongly agree.  Thank you for laying out so many compelling arguments against term limits.  Adding on, Steyer's advocacy for Congressional term limits cannot be adopted without a Constitutional amendment given a Supreme Court decision in U.S. Terms Limits, Inc. v. Thornton that bans Congressional term limits.  A constitutional amendment is a very heavy lift and in my opinion shows his lack of seriousness for his position.  At the very least, when running for President, I would appreciate someone who has done some basic homework about how our system works and what is possible to do as a President.  Finally, his support for national referenda is another misguided proposal--one just needs to look at Brexit to see how divisive a national referendum can be.

Whether you like them or not, politicians hold a job which requires special knowledge   That job is governing.  And it's a skill that is different from running a business for profit.  I've done that.  Governing, in it's purest form,  is a not-for-profit affair.   I'm now a very minor elected public official--a school committee member.  It has taken me nearly all of my first 3 year term to learn what I need to know to be reasonably effective.  Dealing with limited resources, providing what's best for students without forever asking  taxpayers for more money, is a challenge we struggle with every day.  I have been fortunate to be able to lean on the more experienced members of my school committee for mentor-ship, without which I would be lost.  The price of term limits is inexperience, repeated over and over again, and institutional knowledge would be placed in a museum, like so many coats of armor from the days of old.

Legislators are elected by the voters of a state to represent the interests of the people. Sometimes a state's economy is dominated by only one or two employers. A lawmaker would be remiss to ignore that corporate or company linked to the public interest, to further a grand institutional plan or scheme, even if grounded in near universal support throughout the country. A lawmaker from West Virginia or Wyoming is usually working for his constituents, like it or not. Let us all show a little understanding for a politician on the wrong side of history. A firm distinction should be made with those dismissing the wants & needs of labor. Those siding with labor will nearly always be ready to offer an alternative way to avoid environmental or human well being disaster.

Leave the decision to keep or discard a politician to the voters.

In addition, if legislators need to find a new job after say ten or twelve years, that seems to be incentive to cozy up to industry where their next job will likely be located. A longer-term legislator may continue until retirement, so they would not benefit as much as someone making sure that they have job security after their term limit is up.

Bouie does not address the cohort that's most in need of term limits: federal judges. In another example of the Founding Fathers failing to forsee how politics can threaten democracy, they granted lifetime appointments for federal judges, thinking that this was the best way to insulate them from political influence. Now, with patently unqualified people on the Supreme Court and Republican Senators flooding the lower courts with hacks, we can see the danger. Term limits for legislators is debatable. Lack of term limits for federal judges is an emergency.

This column is way off the mark. The fact that long serving congresspeople aren't "common" is not the issue. The issue is that the leadership is entrenched, and bought and paid for. 

To use just one example, the absence of term limits gave us Neil Gorsuch instead of Merrick Garland.

As a thought exercise, we have a two-term limit on the presidency. Do you think this should be removed, and the president can stay as long as he (or, hopefully soon, she) can  be re-elected? I advise you to think of an orange example and a red electoral college as you consider your response.

Term limits on all of Congress may be a bit much, I don't know. But term limits on the leadership, or at least their leadership roles, are neither naive nor cynical. Steyer is on to something.
Could not agree more. Thanks for putting that out there in such a cogent manner.

I agree term limits would produce a greater problem not an answer.   And JB offers many sound better approached.

How about increasing terms in the House to 3-4 years as so much of a 2 year term is spent campaigning for the next brief term.

A problem for all politicians is getting re-elected. That’s uses up a lot for time and costs money.
Trump is an extreme example. It seems to be all he ever thinks about. 
The consequence is it takes up far to much of their time and effort. And campaign funding is hugely important.
The ideal it seems could be one term. Then a politician would not face re-election and could not be bought by 
donations to future campaign. So more time to work and think and not overly influenced by money.
As this is the opposite of the current system, anything that moves in this direction is positive.
Term limits, shmerm limits; until the Electoral College is eliminated, this country will never have democracy.

I don't think many Americans know that our first attempt to organize the country, the 1778 Articles of Confederation, HAD term limits. In terms of congressmen, it said "no person shall be capable of being delegate for more than three years, in any term of six years;." That's term limits. When the framers, some of whom had served in the Continetal/Confederation Congress, set about writing the Constitution, they decided these limits were not necessary, thus, the Constitution only has them for the elected members of the Executive branch. Originalists accordingly should oppose any effort to re-insitute term limits, because that is what would happen.

Mr. Bouie,

I have often wondered if term limits would not be a good idea, especially if it might prevent disasters like Mitch McConnell, but your strong argument against term limits is most convincing, as are your proposals for better ways to achieve the improvements to our democracy that term-limit proponents claim to want, but, in fact, may not. 

Sometimes you can judge a political idea by the company it keeps. 

Thanks for opening my eyes. Keep up the good work.

I saw Tom Steyer's TV ads on term limits, and they bugged me for two additional reasons:

1. This is not something that as president of the United States a Tom Steyer could even "do:" only the Congress could impose terms limits on themselves. Which leads into the second problem...

2. It simply ain't gonna happen.

So with all the problems our next president will have to tackle, why even waste any energy talking about term limits, when you should be talking about the real stuff?

Term limits are a feel-good solution in search of a problem. The notion that long-time legislators necessarily become out-of-touch and beholden to lobbyists and contributors is often asserted, but not proven. The real risk, vis-a-vis contributors, is that multi-term legislators, knowing they are highly likely to be re-elected, will put corrupting pressures upon contributors ("I will win with your money or without your money, and without it I might not be particularly interested in getting your bill out of committee...). It's the newbies who are often short of funding. 

If the complaint is so-called "gridlock", note the fact that while our legislators often do a poor job with respect to big national issues, they are closely attentive to the wellbeing of their states and districts. The two are related. A secure long-term incumbent might well be more able, and more disposed, to take on those big issues than a newcomer with only a tenuous hold on office, as the columnist notes. 

The governmental policy system includes far more people and groups than just legislators; why should the only participants we choose directly always be the rookies?

A common reform fallacy is that we can and should enact laws to do our job as citizens for us. In the US, if you want to get rid of a long-time incumbent, get out and vote.  If you want a good example of the effects of term limits, take a close look at Mexico...

We all need to be involved all the time in the political process.  When we see that out politicians don't care about the public then we vote them out of office.  We don't but into the tired old seniority is at stake.  We voted two white politicians one on NYC and the other in Boston out of office out when they thought they were so much smarter than the public and it has worked out well.  We don't miss the old boys club  We the people are represented, for once in a long time.

Term limits are irrelevant if you keep your eye on what these politicians are actually doing in office.  We had a similar discussion about Nancy and look how well it has turned out for democracy and America.

The advantage of term limits is that older politicians are forced out of office before they become old and feeble, and start clinging to power while their abilities and initiative slowly decline. 

One only has to look at the current field of Democratic presidential contenders to see this. Instead of cultivating successors and helping to unify their party, the geriatrics are flailing away at each other, complete with memory lapses and petty tale-telling. 

It’s not that ambition is bad, but the Founders understood that men’s ambition had to be channeled and directed for the good of the people. People live longer these days than they did in the eighteenth century. Nature can no longer be counted on to cull the herd.  Art, in the form of Legislation, and specifically in the form of Constitutional Term Limits, offers the kindest practical alternative.

This column is exactly right. The correct time for a legislator's term of office to end is when they leave voluntarily or don't get re-elected (or, rarely, get recalled).

As Mr. Bouie points out, lobbyists have a huge degree of effective power. But corporate lobbyists (who don't have term limits—maybe they should) are responsible first and foremost to their company's bottom line. Legislators (assuming a functional democracy) are ultimately accountable to voters.

Anything that takes power away from voters, such as term limits, is anti-democratic, and not the kind of "reform" we need now. Reducing the effect of campaign money, getting more fairly drawn districts everywhere, and protecting the vote (especially for those who have been systematically denied it) are better places to focus.

In some fascinating way, term limits are very much like the moveable flood doors being proposed at a cost of $116B for New York Harbor:  Both put a temporary patch on a problem which, as you point out, should be solved rather than patched. 

In the case of the flood doors, climate change is the villain, not a lack of doors in the HUdson River.

IN the case of term limits, removing the inane system of partisan gerrymandering and  making running for office more attractive for those qualified to hold office would solve the term limits problem without gutting our institutional knowledge.

Good column.

There is a country which until 2018 imposed the strictest term limits possible - one term only, no eligibility for reelection ever. That was Mexico. 

The result was corruption on a large scale.

For example, one mayor of Mexico City spent most of his term in office living on an estate in Greenwich, Connecticut, collecting the graft that he was given by the plutocrats.

And most House districts (and many Senate seats) are not competitive, except in the primaries. So if a politician can keep his own party in line, he or she can get reelected with no or nominal opposition in the general election.

The solution is more competition, not artificial term limits.

It works both ways, weakening Bouie's argument.   Good people need to stay in government as long as possible as they hone their expertise.  But bad people, who may outnumber them, need to get out of government as soon as possible, yet they often have the superior funding to remain.  The most powerful solution to this dilemma is probably the hardest, a large cadre of enlightened and engaged voters.
I have a solution: no term limits for politicians we agree with and term limits for those we don’t. Doesn’t that sum it up?

"Just 35" Senators is A LOT! We could have term limits and allow politicians to run again after a "break" in their service - something like an unpaid sabbatical. If their constituents love them so much, they would have another opportunity to serve without having the unfair advantage bestowed upon them by being IN office. I also think getting rid of "Citizens United" would be beneficial.

"Just 35" Senators is A LOT! We could have term limits and allow politicians to run again after a "break" in their service - something like an unpaid sabbatical. If their constituents love them so much, they would have another opportunity to serve without having the unfair advantage bestowed upon them by being IN office. I also think getting rid of "Citizens United" would be beneficial.

Term-limits is just one component of a comprehensive reform package that our democracy needs. Public campaign financing is probably required at the same time as well as strong limits on lobbying for former legislators. I agree with Jamelle Bouie's analysis that term-limits alone will be problematic, but I feel like it can be an element in a larger campaign and corruption reform.

On term limits:  With time, good people get better, bad people get worse.
All people in jobs gain experience: some learn how to make things work better, others learn how to enrich themselves at others' expense better.
What's wrong with term limits: they prevent long-term successes from ever occurring.

There should a middle ground on this issue. I agree that term limits rob our legislative bodies of expertise, but surely, politicians who are holding onto their offices into their 80s are robbing the legislative bodies of other important things (youth, demographic representation of the voters, new ideas, etc.). The middle ground should be an age limit. The U.S. military has a mandatory retirement age of 62 but allows people with special skills to serve until 68. One institution that both Democrats and Republicans respect is the military: respect their decision on this and adopt it for all elected offices in America.

I'm not sure about any value in term limits, but one thing that we aren't hearing from candidates is something that would greatly improve the ability of our elected officials to focus on doing the work needed by their constituents.

Publicly fund campaigns. Easy to say, tricky maybe to produce a workable approach, but the current environment demands that pretty much once they take their oath, elected officials have to do one or both of the following
1 - spend a great deal of time trying to raise funds for reelection
2 - try to find who is willing to give them big checks, reducing hours needed in #1

Fundraising time is time away from becoming an able, effective elected official.

Saving time by going for big checks ties the official since the checks have big strings attached.

With current election laws, a 2-year term in the House involves about one year on public business, and one on fundraising.  This part needs to change. Then when the voters see how their representative is doing - with ability to focus on the job - the voters can decide if that person stays or goes next election.

The system without term limits that Jamelle supports has delivered a self-reinforcing Congress with leadership that excludes new members who do not tow the party line.  Mitch McConnell exists because of lack of term limits. Congress is in the business of maintaining power through rules and structure designed to maintain party and individual power.  It is also an institution where dynastic rule has taken root.  Kennedy, Gore, Bush, Sarbanes, Clinton, Pence, Romney, Udall, Sununu, and the list goes on and on.  Government is dysfunctional and the writer is wrong.  Change is necessary

I wholly agree with Mr. Bouie.  The problem isn't the people in office, it's the people who pay them.  Sever the connection between people in office and monied interests and you remove the incentive for corruption.
1. Publicly finance elections
2. Limit election season to 6 weeks like they do in England
3. Disallow legislators from becoming lobbyists for X number of years after they leave office.

Some of the problems we have may be solved not by term limits, but - and I'm the contrarian here, I'm sure - by making terms in the House 4 years (or even six to match the Senate) instead of two. A Representative takes his/her first year in office just learning the job, and the second year raising money and running for office, thereby corrupting the system with money they need to raise from various sources and interests. Then, if reelected, they now spend half of each term again raising money and seeking reelection. Also, an unpopular vote in the House that's also good for the country won't influence the Representative who may have more than one year for that vote to be shown to be correct (or wrong), an having to defend it immediately and constantly. Other problems could be solved by this solution, too, but M. Mouie is correct. Term limits give us inexperience where it's needed. JMHO.

Yes, you've convinced me.  Everything ELSE in the voting process needs to be addressed: gerrymandering, voter registration, etc.. as you said.  It's like free speech. Don't limit bad speech, counter it with good speech; winning arguments, our better angels.  Don't 'fix' errors in democracy by hindering democracy.  Fix it by maximizing then party neutrality of representative democracy.  Have the voters pick their representatives instead of the other way around.

I first became aware of Tom Steyer years ago through his Impeach Trump ads. Now he’s running for President. I have nothing against Mr. Steyer, but it seems to me that his most visible constituency is his money. 

I would suggest that having begun by calling for this impeachment process, Mr. Steyer could spend  more of his money on a campaign in the Red States making the case for a real impeachment trial for the President, one that would include relevant evidence and witnesses. 
If he used his money now to focus on Republican Senators and the oath that they have all taken to be impartial where they live, it could have a profound impact on the outcome.

It is true that term limits can deprive the legislative branch of necessary expertise and leadership skills.  On the other hand, it was by continually re-electing the same people to Congress, that Southern and some other small states have been able, for most of our history, to lock in control of Congress, to an extent totally disproportionate to their populations. 

A fair and reasonable compromise would be to have no term limits for election to either house of Congress, but  those who have served for more than 12 years would be ineligible to serve as committee chairs, party leaders or Speaker of the House.

Your article echoes exactly my experience when I worked for state government. Lawmakers would spent lots of time trying to learn the intricacies of governing when they were new. Who had the knowledge to "help" them? Lobbyists.
Money for campaigning is also a big issue, as well as the revolving door system of government to private industry where people can use their influence after they have left office.
The answer? Money out. Oversight and accountability in.

I almost always agree with you Mr. Bouie, and so I had to take a step back and consider your stance on this. After reflection, I'm afraid I still don't agree with you.

Despite the statistics you note that show that "unending" terms aren't the majority of cases, they still are prevalent enough to allow for abuse of power and stagnation of change. These are reasons enough to enact term limits. But your claim that having higher turnover leads to "weaker" representatives due to their inexperience, is based on the presumption that these "naive" leaders will be prey to devious and powerful special interests and lobbyists. Even if under current laws around lobbying this is true, the answer isn't to keep people in power longer and give them more power, but to reform and rewrite the rules, and to enforce them.

Clearly our system is broken, and much of the cause is the overwhelming influence of money funneled to our leaders by special interests, and those who have seniority and the power that goes with that, get the most, and therefore are obligated to run things for the money providers. We must end this corrupt system! Perhaps we will learn that term limits are too restrictive and cause the problems you suggest, but most Americans would be willing to test that theory. Do you really believe that McConnell would be able to have thwarted democracy as he has done, from Garland to Trump, if h was term-limited? That alone is reason enough for them.

Tom Steyer is a bit of a con man - he wanted help with the impeachment but then decided to run - he was not honest from the beginning and if he really wants to help progressive principles he should, like Bloomberg, spend to help elect Democrats to the Senate and register voters.

I’m sorry, but you’re wrong just based on the fact that Mitch McConnell is currently the longest serving Senator, and is the perfect example kind of leadership we get from no term limits. One needs to look no further for the out of touch, imperialist mindset he brings to our government.

I agree with you on term limits, but the "center" of Tom Steyer's platform is Climate Change. He vows to declare a national emergency on the first day in office. You may disagree, but I believe climate change is the bigger issue, and the one worth basing my vote on.

I appreciate Mr. Bouie's views in this Op-Ed, and while I agree that (1) were there nonpartisan redistricting in all 50 states, and (2) were there public financing of campaigns, and let's be honest, (3) were Citizens United overturned or, better, ruled moot by a Constitutional Amendment, then the idea of term limits would be unnecessary and, perhaps, harmful.

Meanwhile, down in Mississippi where I was raised, there is a Republican stranglehold on the state, well-funded by money and lies.  It will take more than redistricting and changes to money in politics to strike down what is largely a white-boy plutocracy down there (and fyi, I am a white boy).  It would take some major legal action to curtail the "questionable" tactics and actions of those few and wealthy who shudder at the thought of Mississippi not being under their collective thumb.

But more to the point, the very idea that experienced legislators are needed in Congress points to the very problem with Government - and ironically, Republicans agree with this: "government" is a morass of overly complicated and needlessly complex "stuff".

Governing need not be so convoluted.  Most anyone should be able to grasp the goings-on in Congress, and if not, something is wrong.

Ergo, something is wrong, and redistricting, getting money (and religion) out of politics, and more will not fix it.

What might fix it is less government, more efficiency, and transparency in (most) All Things, thus an ethical Congress.

Jamelle Bouie is absolutely correct.  The real problems with long serving legislators not well serving those they represent can be addressed in much more effective ways than term limits.  Many of these making elections more fair and open to all qualified candidates, reducing burdens both to casting a ballot, universal registration, and elimination of gerrymandered districting are all very worthy and important ideas.  Unfortunately most are unlikely to be supported by incumbent legislators who benefit from maintaining the current system.  Perhaps one Mr. Bouie can add to his list of suggestions is the ability to add through voter petition proposals to not only state and local but national/federal election ballots.  While the proposals may not immediately become law it would demonstrate to our legislators overwhelming public support for some issues.  Petitions could be allowed on both sides of proposals to allow for expression by all voters.  Controversial and or popular proposals on federal ballots would also assist in encouraging increased turnout for elections, a good thing.

I think you are correct. Fresh lawmakers are fresh meat for lobbyists and career influencers of legislators. Those well-funded, unelected advocates don't put term limits on themselves, and they get very good at what they do. Having a few old dogs in the pound, crafty politicians who've weathered multiple elections and heard multiple pitches from lobbyists, can be as much a boon to sound legislation as a drag. 

Let the people decide. My faith in their collective wisdom has been shaken by the rise of Trump, but I don't see how kicking legislators out of office just because they've won a couple of elections will improve things.

The term limit on the presidency isn't a good idea either.  Experience certainly must be a plus in that office as well.  Presidents should have to defend what they do in their second term if they want to run for a third.  The way it is now the president isn't really held to account for the second term at all.  As the amendment was written, Truman, as the last president eligible to do so, could have run for a third term in 1952, but he knew there was no way he could win that election.

Thank you so much for this well researched and well reasoned article.  The knee jerk call for term limits gets me crabby every time.  Here in Oregon we have mostly excellent representation by some of the longer serving Senators and Congresspeople and I for one am very grateful for their expertise and dedication. Thanks too for offering the right alternatives: easier voting, fair districting and limitations on special interest contributions.

I think the  belief in term limits as being a net positive is partially tied to the trend of devaluing true expertise, talent, and experience and overvaluing "relatability" and being "in touch" in politics and in so many other disciplines. 

Of course when it comes to something people REALLY value like a Doctor to perform life saving surgery on a family member or a Quarterback to lead your favorite team everyone wants the expert, the best, the one with the track record.

There are a lot of things I want to say in response to this column, but time is limited so I'll zone in on the biggest flaw: 

Economists have absolutely no idea what constitutes productivity. Let me briefly explain.

In neoclassical theory, your wages reflect your net (or "marginal") contribution to your firm. If your marginal productivity is high, you get a high wage. If it's low, you get a low wage. This is called the marginal productivity theory. Later variations of this theory evolved into human capital theory, the idea that your wages reflect your individual skills and abilities (ie. "human capital"). I'm simplifying things for the sake of brevity, but that's the basic framework implicitly endorsed by David in this column. 

But there's a problem here. What is productivity? Economists have absolutely no way of defining it separately from the very thing they want to explain: wages. They are reduced to a circular argument: productivity explains wages, but we first need to measure wages to know about productivity. A causes B, then B causes A! Productivity is difficult to compare in the real world. How do you compare the output of a farmer to that of a computer programmer? 

David cited a few studies in this column. These studies just look at sales per worker and assume that this qualifies as productivity. But again, they have no way of looking at productivity apart from the firm's revenue, so they're just measuring revenue and calling it productivity.

There are a lot of things I want to say in response to this column, but time is limited so I'll zone in on the biggest flaw: 

Economists have absolutely no idea what constitutes productivity. Let me briefly explain.

In neoclassical theory, your wages reflect your net (or "marginal") contribution to your firm. If your marginal productivity is high, you get a high wage. If it's low, you get a low wage. This is called the marginal productivity theory. Later variations of this theory evolved into human capital theory, the idea that your wages reflect your individual skills and abilities (ie. "human capital"). I'm simplifying things for the sake of brevity, but that's the basic framework implicitly endorsed by David in this column. 

But there's a problem here. What is productivity? Economists have absolutely no way of defining it separately from the very thing they want to explain: wages. They are reduced to a circular argument: productivity explains wages, but we first need to measure wages to know about productivity. A causes B, then B causes A! Productivity is difficult to compare in the real world. How do you compare the output of a farmer to that of a computer programmer? 

David cited a few studies in this column. These studies just look at sales per worker and assume that this qualifies as productivity. But again, they have no way of looking at productivity apart from the firm's revenue, so they're just measuring revenue and calling it productivity.

There's a bit of a problem with the term 'productivity'. It is generally understood to mean that if a given number of employees work harder, they are more productive. That is, they produce more goods for their employer thus raising the company's profit. The calculation is: total profit divided by number of employees equals productivity measured as profit per employee. However, some companies work the equation the other way. The number of employees is reduced, the remaining employees are expected to work harder and the total profit remains the same. Now the calculation yields a higher profit per employee because there are fewer employees generating the same profit. Fine for the company but not so good for those laid off.

Finally, a conservative not a sociological column from Brooks. He didn’t mention that labor unions reward non-productive employees, who would otherwise be left by the wayside. Minimum wages do the same thing.

An example of how American companies increase productivity.

The Company (in Xtown) employs 13,000 workers earning $18 an hour or $36,000 a year. They need to increase productivity. So they fire 3,000 workers who make fewer widgets per day than their fellows.

The laid-off workers find jobs involving a deep fryer and potatoes, at $12 an hour. Three thousand people are now hovering near poverty at $24,000 a year. 

The Company further increases production by making it known that if individual numbers don’t go up, the slackers will be laid off in the next round of firings.
